ab.title: Exodus 16
ab.l:
And journeyed from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel came
to the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and
Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month
after their departing from the land of Egypt.

And
the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses
and Aaron in the wilderness.

And
the children of Israel said to them, ‘Who would make it so that we had died
by the command of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat
by the meat cauldrons, and when we ate bread to the full. Because
you have brought us out to this wilderness to kill this
whole assembly with hunger.’

And
the Lord said to Moses, ‘Lo, I will rain bread
from the skies for you, and the people shall go out and gather
every day, that I may test them,
whether they will walk my ways or not.

And it shall be
that on the sixth day they shall prepare that which they bring in,
and it shall be twice as much as they gathered
every day.’

And Moses and Aaron said
to all the children of Israel, ‘At evening you shall know that the Lord
has brought you out from the land of Egypt.

And at dawn,
you shall see the honour of the Lord because he has heard your
murmurings against the Lord. And we: what are we that
you murmur against us?’

And Moses said,
‘When the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening and
bread to the full at dawn, because the Lord has heard your
murmurings which you murmur before him — and
we: what are we? Your murmurings are not against us, because
|they are| against the Lord.’

And Moses spoke to Aaron,
‘Say to all the congregation of the children of Israel, “Come near before
the Lord, because he has heard you murmurings.”’

And it was, as Aaron spoke to the whole congregation of the children of Israel,
that they turned toward the wilderness, and, lo, the divine Presence of the Lord
appeared in the cloud.

And the Lord spoke
to Moses, saying,

‘I have heard
the murmurings of the children of Israel. Speak
to them, saying, “At twilight you shall eat
meat, and at dawn you shall be filled with bread. And you shall know
that I am the Lord your God.”’

And it was in the evening,
and the quails went up and covered the camp.
And at dawn drops of dew were around
the camp.

And the drops of dew had gone up, and,
lo, there were fine groats on the face of the wilderness, as fine
as frost on the ground.

And
the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another, ‘It is a gift
from God,’ for they did not know what it was. And Moses said
to them, ‘This is the bread which the Lord has given you for food.

This is the word which the Lord has commanded, “Gather of it
every man according to his eating, a measure called omer for each person,
according to the number of your souls, take every man for them who are in his tents.”’

And the children of Israel did so, and
gathered, the one who gathered much and the one who gathered little.

And they measured it with a measure called omer,
and the one who gathered much did not gather too much,
and the one who gathered little did not gather too less,
but they gathered every man according to his eating.

And Moses said them, ‘Let no man leave any of it
until the morning.’

But they did not listen to Moses, and
people left |some| of it until the morning, and to became maggot infested, and
it bred worms after it stank. And Moses was angry with them.

And they gathered it at every
dawn, every man according to his eating, and when the sun grew hot,
it melted.

And it was: on the sixth
day they gathered twice as much bread, two measures
for |each| one, and all the princes of the congregation came and told
Moses.

And he said to them, ‘This is what
the Lord has said, “At daybreak is the day of complete rest, the holy Sabbath to the Lord.
Bake that which you would bake in the stove, and boil that which
you would boil in a pot, and all the surplus lay aside
for yourself to be kept until dawn.”’

And
they laid it up until dawn, as Moses commanded,
and it did not stink, and there was no worm in it.

And
Moses said, ‘Eat it today, because today is a Sabbath to the Lord.
Today you will not find it in the field.

Six
days you shall gather it. And on the seventh day is a Sabbath,
there will be none.’

And it was: on the seventh day
some of the people went out to gather, but they found none.

And the Lord said to Moses, ‘How long will you not want to keep
my commandments and my teachings?

See
that the Lord has given you the Sabbath. On account of this he
gives you on the sixth day the bread of two days.
Abide, each man in his borders. Let no man go out of his borders
on the seventh day.’

So the people rested
on the seventh day.

And
the house of Israel called the name of it: manna. And it was
like coriander seed in size, and it looked white,
and the taste of it was like the honey in the honeycomb.

And Moses said, ‘This is the word which the Lord has commanded: to take:
‘a full measure that is called omer of the manna to be kept
for your generations, so that they may see the bread with
which I have fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you out from the land
of Egypt.”’

And Moses said to Aaron, ‘Take
a basket, and put there a full measure called omer
of manna in it, and place it before the Lord, to be kept
for your generations,’

As the Lord commanded Moses.
And Aaron placed it before the law, to be kept.

And the children of Israel ate manna
forty years until they came to settled land.
They ate the manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.

And an omer was the tenth part
of an ephah.
